For a monoid $M$ and elements $a_{1}, \ldots, a_{n} \in M$, the product is defined as $\prod_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} := a_{1} \cdot \ldots \cdot a_{n}$. A special bracketing on the right-hand side is not necessary due to the associative nature of the law of composition.

The alternating group on $\{1, \ldots, n\}$, denoted as $\mathfrak{A}_{n}$, is the set of all even permutations in $\mathfrak{S}_{n}$, i.e., those permutations for which $\operatorname{sgn} \pi = 1$. It forms a normal subgroup of index 2 in $\mathfrak{S}_{n}$.
Does the concept of a/an Product Notation in Monoids need to be defined for a definition of a/an Alternating Group to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The concept of an Alternating Group involves the set of all even permutations of a symmetric group, which are permutations with a sign of +1. This definition primarily relies on the properties of permutations and their signs, and does not inherently require the concept of product notation in monoids. The product notation in monoids is a general concept used to denote the multiplication of elements in a monoid, which is associative. While permutations can be composed and thus form a monoid under composition, the specific definition of an alternating group does not depend on the general concept of product notation in monoids but rather on the properties of permutations and their signs. Therefore, understanding or defining an alternating group does not necessitate the concept of product notation in monoids.
